history.content:
I don't know if I qualify answering your answer, just want to share some experience. Taking 127, 189 and 170 together and got 1std in 127. What I usually do is to interpret each single slide, with a lot of search on stackexchange to make sure I understand each linalg derivation. Professor was going through the slides super fast, if you could not fully understand each slide, definitely read slowly to digest them one by one with scratch paper by your side after class.

Also, I personally always solve HWs myself without any office hour help or HW party, just by reading slides. (if you have a hard time doing this, start early as each hw is 2weeks!) I found this really helpful though painful at the beginning. Remember that when taking exams, we are required to find hints and link to topics ourselves, which is crucial for model-heavy 127. Trying to solve everything yourself is training you for this skill. The core of the class is extracting model from problem and convert it to a form we had met before, which is very like 170 or 70 or every proof intensive class.  When I took CS70 with Rao and did all HW without office hour, it was a pain because I spent 30+ hour solving HW each week, but it did make me strong because no hint mean you need to try many approaches, which familiarize you with traits of all paths. In addition, it taught me to start early and organize my time. Then exams will become relatively easy if you get enough training. To avoid spending too much time trying to do this during semester, I encourage you to have a try during break. 

Another point I want to make, is taking all implicit pre-reqs. EE16A is not enough since it doesn't teach SVD, EE16B is very important. I read a ton of linalg from MIT OCW and 189 notes before I take the class. Again, make use of your break time.

At the end, I feel like stabbed when 127 grade came out this semester. Professors taught the class really well but curve gave me A- and ruined a perfect GPA. I think the curve this semester is not an accurate reflection of our understanding, so definitely don't be frustrated just because letter grade looks bad. 

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

From my experience this semester, there were a lot of topics in 127 that were really interesting, but we skipped over, as they required more math (convex analysis). One example that I thought was amazing was the connection between the double dual space and the Lagrangian (https://math.stackexchange.com/questions/223235/please-explain-the-intuition-behind-the-dual-problem-in-optimization). But in terms of doing well in the exams, I think a majority of it reduces to being able to reproduce the results found in the slides/textbook/livebook, and so practicing those allowed me to take the exams relatively well. Knowing all the tricks that they use algebraically is important. Of course that approach is less fun, though.

children.subject: I think it largely depends on your self motivation though. It was my first grade ever below A in my life so it's of special meaning.
well i hope you're recovering from your stab wound
Come on. A- is good... It doesn't look bad at all...

history.content: 127’s grades just came out and it turns out its my worse grade at Cal ever. I found the class extremely difficult compared to like 126, 170, etc. It seems like many people are either taking 189 concurrently or have taken it (it was a super intelligent class). This made the competition extremely difficult, not to mention the lack of accessibility of the class. Can someone who has done well in this class point out to me how do I get better at this material? How did you study or learn it? Would taking more math upper divs help with this? Thank you!
history.subject: EECS127 prep
